scenes.title: The Locked Door
scenes.text: The storm broke without warning. Rain hammered the shop's windows like a fist. Alex stood behind the counter, the final customer long gone. They turned the key in the front door, but it just spun. The old lock was stuck. Outside, thunder rattled the panes of glass. Inside, the power hummed, then died. The emergency fluorescents flickered on, casting everything in a stark, cold light. The shop was quiet, but it was a listening kind of quiet.

scenes.title: The Glass-Eyed Choir
scenes.text: Alex walked into the main showroom. Rows of glass cabinets held forgotten treasures. Porcelain dolls sat on velvet-lined shelves. Their painted smiles seemed too wide under the harsh lights. Their glass eyes followed Alex's every move. From the center of the room, a tiny, tinny melody began. A music box, sitting alone on a doily, had opened itself. It played a simple, looping song that was pleasant at first, then maddening.

scenes.title: The Toymaker's Ledger
scenes.text: The back office was cluttered. Stacks of paper, boxes of receipts. A single lamp cast a pool of light on a heavy, leather-bound ledger. It was open to a page of spidery handwriting. The entries were strange. They were not sales records. They spoke of 'families' and 'keeping them whole.' One entry was circled in red ink: 'The Soldier must not leave his Dancer. Their song must be complete.'

scenes.title: The Lonely Dancer
scenes.text: Alex leaned over the music box. A small porcelain ballerina spun on a tiny mirror, her arms outstretched. The music was a simple, sad tune. A dry, rustling whisper seemed to come from the box itself. *'So lonely...'* Alex's eyes scanned the nearby shelves. They saw him. A small, tin soldier, paint chipped from his uniform, standing at attention just inches away.

scenes.title: The Little House
scenes.text: In the corner stood a dollhouse, an exact, detailed replica of the shop itself. Peering inside, Alex saw tiny furniture arranged perfectly. But the little dolls inside were not still. One, a miniature shopkeeper, slowly raised its stiff arm. It pointed, not at anything inside the dollhouse, but across the real room. It pointed directly at the door to the basement workshop.

scenes.title: A Complete Song
scenes.text: Alex turned the page. The toymaker's madness became clear. He believed his creations were alive, and their spirits were bound to their 'families.' The Soldier and the Dancer were the heart of it all. 'To sunder them is to invite chaos,' he wrote. 'To unite them is to soothe the Gilt Cage. The key to the front door is their reward for harmony.'

scenes.title: Empty Sockets
scenes.text: The old filing cabinet was locked tight. Alex pried it open with a letter opener. The metal screeched. Inside, there were no files. Only a pile of broken toy partsâ€”a cracked wooden leg, a bent tin arm. And sitting atop the pile was a single, perfect doll's head. Its painted smile was pristine, but its blue glass eyes had been violently scratched out, leaving two black holes. A child's voice whispered from the cabinet, *'Now you'll stay. You'll be a new toy.'*

scenes.title: The Harmony Key
scenes.text: Alex gently picked up the tin soldier and placed him on the mirrored surface of the music box, beside the ballerina. For a moment, they both stood still. Then, the music changed. It became a gentle, resolved harmony. The sad loop was broken. A soft *click* echoed from the main counter. A small, hidden drawer had sprung open. Inside, nestled on red velvet, was a heavy brass key.

scenes.title: The Discordant March
scenes.text: Alex slammed the lid of the music box shut. The melody cut off with a sickening crunch of gears. A tiny crack appeared on the porcelain ballerina's face. The silence that followed was worse. It was broken by a rhythmic *clash-clash-clash*. A wind-up monkey with cymbals began marching across the floor. Then another toy moved. And another. A small army of animated toys was slowly advancing, their movements jerky and unnatural.

scenes.title: The Collector
scenes.text: The workshop was cold and smelled of sawdust and ozone. A single bare bulb flickered over a workbench littered with tools and parts. The sound of dragging and clicking came from the shadows. Discarded piecesâ€”doll limbs, clockwork gears, wooden blocksâ€”began to pull themselves together. They formed a large, shambling figure, a mockery of a human shape, held together by some unseen will. It was the collector, and it needed new parts.

scenes.title: The Silent Barricade
scenes.text: Alex turned away from the dollhouse, their heart pounding. They had to get out. But when they reached the front of the shop, the way was blocked. Every doll from every shelf was now standing on the floor. They formed a silent, dense crowd between Alex and the door. Dozens of them. Hundreds. Their glass eyes stared forward, reflecting the sterile light in a thousand tiny, cold pinpricks.

scenes.title: The Turn of the Key
scenes.text: With the brass key in hand, Alex walked to the front door. The dolls on the shelves were still, watching. The toys were silent. The only sound was the rain and the frantic beating of Alex's own heart. They pushed the key into the old lock. It slid in smoothly. With a deep, satisfying *clunk*, the lock turned. The door was open.

scenes.title: The Cleansing Rain
scenes.text: Alex stumbled out into the night. The cold rain was a shock, but it was real. It washed the dust and fear away. They looked back. The lights in 'The Gilt Cage' went out, plunging the shop into absolute darkness. The storm was just a storm again. The toys were just toys. Alex turned and walked away, never looking back.

scenes.title: A New Addition
scenes.text: Alex swung the heavy mallet, shattering a porcelain arm. But more parts scrambled to take its place. The creature was a tide of wood and metal. It cornered them against the damp stone wall. There was a splintering crunch. A flash of pain. Then the cold, clicking feeling of clockwork gears meshing with things that were never meant to be clockwork. The collection was made whole again.

scenes.title: The Broken Heart
scenes.text: Ignoring the shambling horror, Alex scanned the workbench. They saw it in a dusty box: a brass and copper heart, pulsing with a faint light. The toymaker's own heart. Alex grabbed the mallet and brought it down. It shattered with a sound like a thousand tiny bells breaking at once. Every toy in the shop fell silent and inert. The spirit was gone. But its final scream echoed in Alex's mind, cracking it like porcelain, leaving them alone in the quiet, broken dark.
